$!You may need to tell DVLA If you've had a coronary artery bypass or disease.$!

%You can be fined up to £1,000 if you don’t tell DVLA about a medical condition that affects your driving. If you’re involved in an accident, you may be prosecuted.%

##Car or motorcycle licence

You don't need to tell DVLA. You should stop driving for at least 1 month and only restart driving when your doctor tell you that you are safe to do so. For further information please download the leaflet 'CLE1066'.

$D
[Download 'CLE1066 - Car or motorcycle drivers with heart conditions' (PDF, 176KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_192828.pdf  "Download leaflet 'CLE1066: Car or motorcycle drivers with heart conditions' (PDF, 176KB)"){:rel="external"}
$D

##Bus, coach or lorry licence

You must tell DVLA. Fill in form VOCH1 and send it DVLA. The address is on the form.

$D
[Download 'VOCH1 - Confidential medical information' (PDF, 394KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_065302.pdf "Download medical questionnaire"){:rel="external"}
$D

*[DVLA]: Driver Vehicle and Licensing Agency
overview: You may need to tell DVLA If you've had a coronary artery bypass or disease - if you do, download the correct form to let them know
title: Coronary artery bypass or disease and driving
